page.title: 02 CHURCHES - Wootton Wawen
page.content: There are two churches in the village.{St. Peter's,}the Established Church, still has traces of the original Saxon building: some sanctuary arches, traces of roof ridges and herringbone masonry. Much building took place in Norman times (1066-1154) but important alterations and additions date from the reigns of early Plantagenet kings (1154-1377). Further additional and restoration work has been carried out right up to the present day. The Roman Catholic church is called{St. Benedict's. }An early R.C.} chapel, built in 1813, stands in the grounds of{Wootton Hall}but it is no longer used as a chapel. During the time of religious persecution a Benedictine monk lived in the Hall.
